- tried again with no changes, and it worked OK

Note that I don't have any of the runtime or OSGI plugins in my workspace.
D:/eclipse-I20040212-0800 is my host install (correct).

When you tried to run the first instance, did you just ended a previous session 
(that could have been unterminated) ?

Also, Nick, could you add the previous session to this PR? We have another PR
that may cause two session headers to be written for one actual Eclipse session.

I don't believe I had just exited the target, although it's possible.

Here's the log from the previous session, or at least the previous session that 
generated some output (this was using I20040210-1600).

The two stack dumps are due to a problem in the instrumentation plugin, which I 
did not add to the install when I switched to the I20040212-0800 build.
Just in case the problem was due to this change in install, I tried going back 
to the earlier build, launching my target, exiting both, running the newer 
build, launching my target again.  But the IllegalStateException did not occur 
again.

Nevermind Nick, you are right, the timestamps in the previous session show they
are completely unrelated.

Recent builds will refuse to start if any of the essential bundles (OSGi
framework, services, util, runtime, configurator) have not started properly. The
error Nick got shows that the configurator was not properly activated, and this
was the reason it crashed. The reason the configurator failed to start is the
real question to be answered, and unfortunately, we have no clues about that
because, for some reason (maybe bug 51268), it is not in the log.
what is the status of this?

I cannot reproduce this and we don't have any further info on why the update
configurator didn't start (which is why Eclipse didn't start). Closing. Nick,
please reopen if you see it again.
